Posts.Content: If you had a biopsy done and the tissue was tested for estrogen and progesterone "receptors" and the result was negative, that means that you currently do not have estrogen or progestrone receptor-positive breast cancer cells. (Your doctor should really be answering your questions.) Estrogen and progesterone positive receptors means that your cancer therapy and adjuvant therapies will be targeted specifically at reducing those female hormones and estrogen receptors in your body so the estrogen receptor positive cancer cells will be starved. If you are "negative", that means that conventional chemo, not hormone-type treatments, would be recommended. Consider yourself lucky. Treatments that prevent cells from absorbing estrogen are very defeminizing, to say the least. Your tissue should also have been tested for HER2NEU, which also requires a targeted therapy. If that was not tested for, you should speak to your doctor and ask if the tissue is still available for further testing. This is a genetic thing, so if you have it your children may get cancer, and males are known to pass this gene on. Anyway, go search the internet for these specific topics and make sure you ask your doctor these questions. She should be your best resource; however, doctors aren't always totally "available" for patients' many questions and concerns.
Posts.Title: negative hormone receptors

Posts.Content: I recently responded to your question about "negative" receptors. You also mentioned radiation post-lumpectomy, with no chemo? I hope your doctor has discussed the very possible side effects of breast radiation, including possible future rib and lung disease, heart damage, etc.
Posts.Title: negative hormone receptors

Posts.Content: I am totally flabbergasted by what your  doctors have led you to believe are limited chances of survival!  You're only in stage 2B, if you're correct about that?  I advise getting the opinions of another oncologist or two IMMEDIATELY and hiring an attorney to bring malpractice charges against these clear idiots who have given you no hope, it seems.  They made you think your chances are minimal.  Insanity!! Incompetence!  Run, don't walk, to another institution and provider on Monday.  I still can't get over it.  There's always hope!  Are you kidding?  There are so many drugs available now as opposed to even 5 years ago.  Are your doctors  old?  Often, these"old school" oncologists aren't totally familiar with things happening today and they're trained to deal with breast cancer sufferers as if death is imminent.  It is't.  Please, I beg that you take my advice and either confront your doctors directly with a best friend or partner with you and tell them that you are not satisfied with their conclusion!  There's no spread, so you're not even metastatic, and the only thing is two armpit nodes.  I'm just sitting here and  shaking my head and knowing this attitude is why women keep dying from breast cancer. I've had metastatic disease with widespread metas since 1996.  I'm not alone.  We're still living. The worse thing you could do is just accept what they say. I think you said you had surgery.  Surgery, radiation and chemo is a very unusual approach to stage 2B.  I would be careful of over-treatment as many oncologists are winging it, take it from one who was over-treated and suffers the lasting effects.  Again, GETE ANOTHER OPINION for treatment.
Posts.Title: SO Scared!

Posts.Content: On 6/1/2007 Delia Margaret wrote: Advice needed.  Since taking Arimadex and then changing to Aromasin six months ago< I have developed HUGE swollen feet.  Two sizes larger and wider than normal. Resulting in my having to wear man's shoes or have shoes made.  My hands are like packets of sausages and I cannot wear any rings. This is causing me a degree of stress as I feel very ugly.  Is there anybody who has the answer for this?  I am going to a wedding abroad next month and am heartbroken at the thought of wearing sneakers!!!!! Please can anybody tell me what to do? Delia I took Arimidex for four years and had huge negative consequences and became very "mannish", but never had unusual swelling. Is Arimidex the only drug you're taking? Did you tell your doctor that you have this problem? You might ask your doctor if you can suspend treatment for a week or two to see what happen s. A week or two off of a treatment never really hurt anybody. Do you really need estrogen suppression? I wish you the best but always complain and  complain andcomplain about side effects to your doctor and don't leave the office without answers.
Posts.Title: Oestragen Blocker and consequenses

Posts.Content: On 2/13/2008 didi719 wrote: I had a bi-lateral mastectomy 7/07.  Since I did not have lymph node involvement I did not have to have radiation or chemo. I have been taking Arimidex since my cancers were ER+. I have absolutely NO libido whatsoever. Has anyone else experienced this and is there any treatment?
Posts.Title: Loss of libido after bi-lateral mastectomy and Arimidex

Posts.Content: My message to you was cut off.  Your doctors won't tell you that you will become a man with Arimidex or any other estrogen-suppression cancer therapy because THEY aren't enduring trans-sexualizing cancer therapy.  Do you know that European female body builders use Arimidex to develop bigger muscles and to become less feminine?  No you don't.  When one gets Arimedex, one agrees to have their femaleness destroyed.  That's all I can say, as a former user of  it.   After three and a half years on Arimedex, I myself decided to stop the therapy, without my oncologists's input or consent.  And when I told him that I thought it was too damaging to me as a woman, he suggested yet another estrogen suppressing drug.  At that point, I said to myself, my life is my hands and I have to stop the pharmaceutical abuse. What would he know, anyway.  They go by what the pharmeceutical companies tell them, make no mistake. Estrogen suppression therapy is only appropriate for men with prostate disease.  Good luck to ladies who can't say, wait a minute, I want to get some  more information, I want a week or two to do research, I want two more opinions,  I only wish I knew in 1996 what I know  now. .  .
Posts.Title: Loss of libido after bi-lateral mastectomy and Arimidex

Posts.Content: My suggestion is that your onco do a bone scan at least to see if there is any actual bone deterioration.  If not, see an orthopedic oncologist for a consultation. You should also get a bone density scan. I developed many bone and joint issues while on Arimidex. You should be receiving a bone protectant such as Zometa or Aridia. Speak frankly to your onco about your concerns.
Posts.Title: arimadex side effects

Posts.Content: On 6/13/2007 Laura a wrote: I'm having slight joint pains after 2 years that seems to be building. One lady in my support group mentioned cutting the pill (man, it is tiny though) in half and taking 2 does AM & PM helped her. I've started doing more with Omega 3 (fish oil) & glucosamine chondroitin recently. Don't know if it will help, but at least I feel pro-active!  Anyone tried this approach?  Laura  I took Arimedex for almost 4 years, and quit it because of all the side effects. However, as far as I know there is only one strength of Arimedex. Also, as I have read, you don't know the distribution of the drug within the tablet. If you don't like Arimedex, ask your provider about alternatives to it. All aromatase inhibitors are lousy and do bad things to your body, mind, sexuality, and bones, so keep up with your bone health with bone scans and bone density testing.

However, as far as I know there is only one strength of Arimedex. Also, as I have read, you don't know the distribution of the drug within the tablet. All aromatase inhibitors are lousy and do bad things to your body, mind, sexuality, and bones, so keep up with your bone health with bone scans and bone density testing.
Posts.Title: arimedex

Posts.Content: Run, don't walk, to another onco.  If you are her2neu+ and estrogen receptor positive and your doctor hasn't advised you about immediate treatments for both, confront him at once or find yourself another onco fast.  For her2neu:  only about 15% of female breast cancer patients are her2neu+  There are 2 targeted therapies for it: Herceptin, and Tykerb. Information for both is available online.  Just type in the individual words and do a search.  I have it.  I use it.  Have cancer since 1996.  Additionally, it is a genetic marker which means you've inherited it through your mother or father.  It can be passed by males.  Does someone on either side have/had cancer?  Many targeted therapies are available for ER+ too, so don't be so down!  This stuff is highly treatable.  But since it is a genetic marker, your sisters or daughters should be screend as early as possible, and though it may not be covered by insurance, $150 for a mammo is well worth it.  National Cancer Institute also has lots of info; National Institutes of Health, etc.  Tykerb is made by GlaxoSmithKline; go there. ER+, Arimidex, made by AstraZeneca.  Herceptin is made by Genentech Bio-oncology.  Visit them too.  Ask the onco for a PET scan to rule out metastases.  Chest x-ray too.  BE WELL-INFORMED AND PROACTIVE ON YOUR OWN BEHALF!  All the best to you.
Posts.Title: her2 neu pos and very scared. I need help!

Posts.Content: Sounds to me like you're parrotting a doctor or other healthcare person.  Calcium and vitamin D have nothing to do with the hormonal , ageing, and defeminizing effects of Arimidex.
Posts.Title: Arimidex side effects

Posts.Content: My suggestion is that you use your computer time getting specific information about Arimidex and Aromisin.  Just enter those words on your search bar and you'll see many sites available.  Arimidex and Aromasin are different but I can't say how; just go to their individual websites.  You'll be able to get manufacturers info usually just available to doctors.  When I complained to my doctor about the terrible effects of Arimidex, he suggested Aromasin.  I just said forget about it and haven' t used any kind of estrogen-related drug for years, except for Faslodex, which made me go bald and grow a moustache that I have to shave every day.  Your doctor is responsible for giving you as much information as possible; however, they usually don't.  In my own history I've found Arimidex is profoundly damaging to bone and destroyed my femaleness and my sexuality--after all, it is an estrogen suppressor and the company's own advertising states it causes osteoporosis, joint and bone pain, etc., etc.  If you take any type of estrogen-interfering drug, make sure you've done your own research, because they are very damaging and your doctor doesn't care if you lose your hair or have painfull intercourse or have to shave every day or your bones fall apart.  They only care that you are a positive statistic--one who survives, at any cost..
Posts.Title: Aromasin vs. Arimidex
